channel.title: Music on Tobyblog
channel.description: Recent content in Music on Tobyblog

item.title: Today's Sounds: It's Possible
item.description: Forever remind yourself. The comments section on this video describes it as 70’s Italian cocaine lounge music. Psychedelia. Dunno, but I like it. I suppose this goes out to all you folks tripping today in Oregon.

item.title: Garth Alper ‚Äî¬†Stratus
item.description: This is the guy that taught me and Kass to appreciate jazz, literally. He was our old jazz and music appreciation professor in college. On a couple of occasions we went to see him and his band play around town. Neat guy, and some people said we kind of resembled each other. I always found this sound makes for good study music. This is his third album, I believe, and it’s pretty strong.

item.title: Pretty People
item.description: Currently enjoying this sweet cover of one of my favorite Blossom Dearie tracks. That’s not the only Blossom Dearie song they cover, too. Apparently somebody over there is a fan. If there were more covers of her music I’d love to do another cover battle, but alas. Blossom is too much underappreciated.

item.title: How Old Am I?
item.description: Strolling towards 50 like

item.title: Music From Empty Malls
item.description: My working playlist for today. Makes me think about remoting from the old Collin Creek mall. I miss that place.

item.title: Happy Birthday, Curtis Mayfield. RIP
item.description: I’m afraid we’re all out of Curtis Mayfields.

item.title: Cover Battle ‚Äî Killing in the Name
item.description: Recent events got me resurrecting an old feature of the site that I’ve neglected far too long. Today’s YouTube cover battle features Rage Against the Machine’s “Killing in the Name."

item.title: Liturgical Music for Holy Week
item.description: Some of what I’ve been up to over the past week. This is a recording of the church choir taken after Palm Sunday liturgy. I believe it’s meant to be instructional for the other cantors who will be assisting during Holy Week services.

item.title: RIP ‚Äî¬†Bill Withers üíÄ
item.description: I found out Bill Withers died today. Not a huge fan, but I am rather fond of this one of his. I used that song in the intro to one of my old videos, one I did with Augie back in my personal golden age of geocaching. I miss those days.

item.title: Corona Virus Rap - Gmac Cash
item.description: While I’m at it I might as well post this, too, since Josh got such a kick out of it. I sent this to him a week or so ago, then days later he’s in the hospital. Great timing on my part. Maybe he didn’t follow soon enough the sober and thoughtful advice given in this video. Get well, my brother.

item.title: The Covid-19 Blues
item.description: Just got this from my brother, who at this moment is being hospitalized in Louisiana for pneumonia and possible coronavirus infection. Still awaiting results of his 2nd test. Hasn’t killed his sense of humor. We love you, Josh. Get well.

item.title: This Soft Jazz Will Cure Your Coronavirus
item.description: I guess it’s true that there really is a jazz for every conceivable mood or situation.

item.title: Reduce Your Anxiety
item.description: Is this the most chill song in the world? In fact, listening to that one song ‚Äî ‚ÄúWeightless‚Äù ‚Äî resulted in a striking 65 percent reduction in participants‚Äô overall anxiety, and a 35 percent reduction in their usual physiological resting rates. I have a lot of tracks I listen to alter or set my mood, but I’ve never seen the phenomenon quantified so neatly. I’d like to see the measurable improvements in focus, attention, or creativity that music is capable of producing.

item.title: Music for Black Friday Shopping
item.description: For all you folks out there enjoying the savings and discounts, and perhaps needing a little mood music to go along with. You might recognize that one. It’s sort of famous. Here’s a link to the entire playlist, which I don’t seem to be able to embed on my page. Maybe that doesn’t even make sense. The 1950s gave birth to shopping music, and I’m not sure its bright and chipper tone has ever been topped.

item.title: Metallica-Enter Sandman (Smooth Jazz Version)
item.description: NEW PERMANENT MOOD.

item.title: Rage Against the Machine - Bulls on Parade But It's Stayin' Alive by Bee Gees
An Album for September
item.description: Doing chores, having a ü•É while I listen to Frank‚Äôs album about growing old.

item.title: Love Is a Many Splendored Thing
item.description: One of my earliest memories is asking my mom to borrow an old Hallmark music box that played this song. It was important to me, though I couldn’t explain why. I’d listen to it over and over again, long past the point of annoyance to everyone. Sometimes at night, when I was scared, I’d listen to it to help me sleep. It has a sad, but sweet melody. At about 2:00 it has the proper timing, then very quickly starts to unwind.

item.title: Guns N Roses
item.description: It occurred to me today, as I was getting my hair cut, that Guns N‚Äò Roses really jumped the shark with November Rain. In fact, I‚Äôd say November Rain is what killed Hair Rock.

item.title: Save The Children
item.description: I just want to ask a question Who really cares? To save a world in despair Who really cares? There‚Äôll come a time, when the world won‚Äôt be singing Flowers won‚Äôt grow, bells won‚Äôt be ringing Who really cares? Who‚Äôs willing to try to save a world Thats destined to die When I look at the world it fills me with sorrow Little children today are really gonna suffer tomorrow

item.title: Guess Who's Coming to Dallas?
item.description: Well, well. And I thought they’d retired. I suppose there are still a few living acts I’d pay to see after all. üê¶üêù No idea whether we’ll make it out to this one, but might bee nice. Read all about my love for their Hall and Oates cover album. And give those songs a deep listen.

item.title: Deutschland
item.description: Just caught the soft jazz, muzak version of Deutschland Uber Alles over the speakers at Hobby Lobby just now, and had the feeling that I‚Äôd crossed into that alternate timeline where the Germans won WWII.

item.title: Muskrat Love
item.description: Just walked up on two skunks fornicating. üíàüê±‚ù§Ô∏è

item.title: Leaving On A Jetplane
item.description: üõ´üåÉ Well, it‚Äôs been a busy few days. It‚Äôs a lot of work graduating a kid. Between that and home and my professional duties I‚Äôve been swamped. Such is the life of a dad. Since my last teaser post it‚Äôs only now that I feel like I can catch my breath a bit and recollect on some things I‚Äôd like to share with you. Hope you all are having a warm and magical evening.

item.title: Uncle Albert
item.description: Currently enjoying at maximum volume.

item.title: üéß Soulshine
item.description: Don’t you need it?

item.title: Jean ‚Äî¬†Rod McKuen
item.description: Listening.

item.title: Brown Noise Tracks for Intense Focus
item.description:
Over the last couple of weeks I’ve had the need to maintain a greater focus in my work and study. I find brown noise to be good way of filtering out distractions, to allow the mind to concentrate on a task. Brown noise tends to sit at a lower frequency than white noise, so the sound is deeper and more meditative.

Here are some tracks that I like. Use headphones to get the most out of these.

Very low, like a muffled waterfall from a distance. Very good track.

item.title: Current Mood üåõ
item.description: Go ahead. Pour a glass of whiskey ü•É and enjoy this with me, won’t you? Forget about everything you have coming up this week. All that stuff. It’ll wait. Right now just listen for moment. Listen with me. Dim those lights. Turn up the music for a while. Just be. Just close your eyes and listen. Don’t think too much about it. When’s the last time you were ever this‚Ä¶

item.title: I Can't Get Over This Cover Album
item.description:
I discovered the The Bird and Bee this past December when I heard their rendition of The Twelve Days of Christmas at a bar in Honolulu. That led me to this album, and I’ve been burning it up lately on drives and at work.

It’s total ear candy.

item.title: George Michael's Jazz Noir Album
item.description: A pop take on jazz noir from his best album. Many years ago Kass and I listened to this cassette so much we broke the tape. I hope you all are having a mellow moment, whenever it is for you. I know I am. I find jazz noir goes best with whiskey. ü•É

item.title: Welcome to 2019
item.description: Some sounds for dark days, and nights.

item.title: A Few of My Favorite Christmas Songs
item.description: Hands down my favorite Christmas song of 2018. I passed up this album in favor of Jackie Gleason’s Tis The Season, a purchase I do not regret, but this song is definitely worth the price of the vinyl. I love it when Frank sings melancholy, and this one has that quality in spades. Nostalgia, regret, and loneliness are all wrapped up in that golden bow of his amazing voice, a voice that forces your ears to attention when you hear it, never aging, never dulling, calling your life before your eyes, and all but materializing that glass of whiskey or scotch in your left hand, as your right hand reaches to pull the brim of your fedora down a little more to cover the tears in your eyes. Merry Christmas!

item.title: Halloween is Officially On Hold
item.description: October, you have been one long, soggy mess. C’est la vie, I suppose. To commemorate what I anticipate to be tonight’s non-event, I have chosen this song to be the official “hold” music of Halloween 2018, to be played in a continuous loop until one metaphorically throws up one’s hands in disgust, and finally gives up the game. To pick it up again next year? Perhaps. But never quite in the same way.

item.title: So Long, San Francisco
item.description: A song to fit a very particular mood. It’s been a significant week.

item.title: Once Upon a Time, Frank Sinatra
Cover Battle ‚Äî The Great Pumpkin Waltz
item.description: We are officially in the “-BER months” now, a time of year that for my generation is indelibly stamped by the melancholy Peanuts cartoon soundtracks of Vince Guiraldi and his trio. Though the nostalgic quality of these tracks reaches fever pitch around Christmastime, we begin our seasonal contemplation with this wistful little tune, quickly supplanted in the Guiraldi lineup, but never quite forgotten. It remains one of my favorites, but I’ll only listen to it from the start of September through Halloween.

item.title: Cover Battle ‚Äî¬†Love Songs
item.description: It’s time once again for one of my patented YouTube cover battles, and in typical fashion you pick the winner. Tonight’s theme is one of my favorite for YouTube covers ‚Äî LOVE SONGS. I have my personal favorite, of course, but I won’t spoil it for you. Enjoy, and leave a comment to vote for the winner.

item.title: Cover Battle ‚Äî Red Rubber Ball
item.description: I woke up this morning with this song stuck in my head, thinking about my dad and the good progress he’s making recovering from a triple bypass operation.

item.title: Baker Street
item.description: Love this song. Local musician Bruce Wilder was recently performing it solo at Firewheel Coffee, my office away from the office. Makes me want to sneak up behind him with a giant saxophone and start blaring away at the appropriate moments.

item.title: You're Getting Better - Ken Nordine
item.description: My most popular Youtube upload.
